Dear Sunburned,

If I write

assertEquals("(1,-1,0)", point.toString());

a=
nd change the toString method, I get this (slightly garbled, but
mostly hel=
pful) failure:

org.junit.ComparisonFailure: expected:<[(1,-1,0)]> but was:=
<[[1, -1, 0]]>
	at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:123)...

This =
seems to cover the one example you cite.  Are there others?

   David Saff
=


On Fri, Nov 20, 2009 at 1:06 PM, Sunburned Surveyor
<sunburned.surveyor@g=
mail.com> wrote:
> I have a question about the options for gathering and di=
splaying
> supplemental information about test failures. Please allow me to=

> illustrate my question with a simple example.
>
> I've got a class calle=
d Coordinate that represents a point in a 3D
> coordinate system. I've over=
loaded the toString method of this class
> to write out the X, Y, and Z val=
ues of the coordinate in a simple
> String. Now I want to test my toString =
method using JUnit.
>
> If the Coordinate.toString test method fails (becau=
se the string was
> not constructed in the correct format) I would like to =
provide the
> programmer running the test with a copy of the incorrect stri=
ng, since
> it provides valuable clues about what is broken with the method=
 under
> test. I typically do this by placing System.err.println statements=
 in
> my test method. However, I realize that using System.err.println isn'=
t
> the most portable or elegant way to provide this information to the
> p=
rogrammer executing the test.
>
> What I really want is a GUI that allows t=
he programmer to select a
> failed test from a list of failed tests, and th=
en to view supplemental
> test data I provide him/her.
>
> I was thinking I=
 could do this by completing the following tasks:
>
> - Implementing the Ru=
nListener interface in JUnit.
> - Create an extension of Exception that cou=
ld contain a HashMap of
> simple parameters and that would be passed to the=
 constructor of a
> Failure object from within a test.
> - Creating Failure=
 objects in my tests that contain the supplemental
> failrure data.
> - Pas=
sing these failure objects to my RunListener implementaiton.
> - Creating a=
 FailureProcessor class that displays a GUI with the
> information in my Ru=
nListener implemenation to show the programmer
> executing my tests the sup=
plemental failure data as described above.
> (FailureProcessor would be an =
interface so that you could do different
> things with the supplemental fai=
lure data, not just show it in a GUI.)
>
> Before I begin this work, I want=
ed to ask if there was a better way to
> do this. I know I could use a logg=
ing framework from within my test
> method, but I really want to work withi=
n the JUnut framework, not
> outside of it. I also want a nice little GUI, =
not a log file.
>
> How are other programmers handling instances when they =
want to display
> supplemental data on failed tests? Does my approach sound=
 reasonable?
>
> The Sunburned Surveyor
